definition: Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
surname Cai
currency unit (esp. Chinese yuan)/first/original/primary/fundamental/constituent/part/era (of a reign)/meta- (prefix)/(math.) argument/variable/(Tw) (geology) eon
surname Yuan/the Yuan or Mongol dynasty (1279-1368)
to bank up with earth/to cultivate (lit. or fig.)/to train (people)

sentences.english: Yuanpei Cai lived in an era of intense debate on Chinese ethics and culture in contemporary China.
sentences.chinese: 蔡元培生活在近代中國道德文化之爭最爲激烈的年代。

sentences.english: The name of the Ma Ling Mountain House was the inscription by Cai Yuanpei, a great educator and then president of Beijing University.
sentences.chinese: 別名“馬嶺山房”是北大校長教育家蔡元培題寫的。

sentences.english: Both Cai Yuanpei and Alexander von Humboldt are well-known educationalists.
sentences.chinese: 蔡元培和洪堡都是著名的高等教育家。

sentences.english: The article discussed the close relationship between Mr. Cai Yuanpei and the investigation.
sentences.chinese: 本文還論述了蔡元培先生與這次田野調查的密切關係。

definition: Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
Liang Shuming (1893-1988), modern philosopher and teacher in the neo-Confucian tradition
Liu Shipei (1884-1919), Chinese anarchist and revolutionary activist
Li Dazhao (1889-1927), early Chinese Marxist and founding member of the communist party
Song Jiaoren (1882-1913), politician of the revolutionary party involved in the 1911 Xinhai revolution, murdered in Shanghai in 1913
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Zhang Taiyan 章太炎 (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
John Leighton Stuart (1876-1962), second-generation American missionary in China, first president of Yenching University and later United States ambassador to China
Feng Youlan (1895-1990), distinguished Chinese philosopher
Tang Shaoyi (1862-1939), politician and diplomat
Lu Xun (1881-1936), one of the earliest and best-known modern Chinese writers
